tit.e: Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo of southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region)
Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo of southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region)
tit.cmt: タイトルとして、補足の部分は削除しました。

sen.j: 大国主（おおくにぬし）は日本神話の中で、出雲神話に登場する神である。
sen.e: Okuninushi is a god that appears in a type of Japanese Mythology called Izumo Shinwa (Myths of Izumo).
Okuninushi is a god that appears in a type of Japanese Mythology called Izumo Shinwa (Myths of Izumo).
Okuninushi is a god that appears in a type of Japanese mythology called Izumo Shinwa (Myths of Izumo).
sen.cmt: mythology と小文字にしました。

sen.j: 天の象徴である天照大神に対し、大地を象徴する神格でもある。
sen.e: While Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) symbolizes the sky, Okuninushi symbolizes the earth.
While Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) symbolizes the sky, Okuninushi symbolizes the earth.
While Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) symbolizes the sky, Okuninushi symbolizes the earth.

tit.cmt: 小タイトル用に小文字にしました。

sen.j: 大国主は多くの別名を持つ。
sen.e: Okuninushi is called by many different names.
Okuninushi is called by many different names.
Okuninushi is called by many different names.

sen.j: これは神徳の高さを現すと説明されるが、元々別の神であった神々を統合したためともされる。
sen.e: It is always explained in terms of virtuousness of Okuninushi, but it is also attributed to the fact that Okuninushi is a result of integration of different gods.
It is always explained in terms of the virtue of Okuninushi, but it is also attributed to the fact that Okuninushi is a result of integrating different gods.
It is always explained in terms of the virtue of Okuninushi, but it is also attributed to the fact that Okuninushi is a result of integrating different gods.

tit.j: 大国主神（おおくにぬしのかみ）
tit.cmt: コロンを追加しました。神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: - 大国を治める帝王の意、あるいは、意宇国主。
sen.e: Okuninushi-no-Kami means an emperor that governs a large country or the lord of Ou.
Okuninushi-no-Kami means an emperor that governs a large country or the lord of Ou.
Okuninushi no Kami means an emperor that governs a large country or the lord of Ou.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: すなわち意宇(おう＝旧出雲国東部の地名)の国の主という説もある。
sen.e: Therefore, there has been a theory that Okuninushi-no-Kami was the lord of Ou (an area in the eastern part of Izumo Province).
Therefore, there has been a theory that Okuninushi-no-Kami was the lord of Ou (an area in the eastern part of Izumo Province).
Therefore, there has been a theory that Okuninushi no Kami was the lord of Ou (an area in the eastern part of Izumo Province).

sen.j: 大汝命（おほなむち）

sen.e: A hoko (long-handled Chinese spear) as in Yachihoko symbolizes military power and the name Yachihoko-no-Kami therefore expresses Okuninushi as a bushin (the god of war).

sen.e: The term 'shikonoo' means a strong man, and these names therefore express Okuninushi as a bushin.

sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

tit.cmt: 小タイトル用に小文字にしました。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』本文によるとスサノオの息子。
sen.e: According to the main body of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Okuninushi was a son of Susanoo (a deity in Japanese Mythology).
According to the main body of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Okuninushi was a son of Susanoo (a deity in Japanese Mythology).
According to the main body of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Okuninushi was a son of Susanoo (a deity in Japanese Mythology).

sen.j: また『古事記』、『日本書紀』の一書や『新撰姓氏録』によると、スサノオの六世の孫、また『日本書紀』の別の一書には七世の孫などとされている。
sen.e: Also, according to ""Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), one of the volumes of "Nihonshoki," and "Shinsen Shojiroku" (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility), Okuninushi was described as the sixth-generation grandson of Susanoo, while he was described as the seventh-generation grandson in a different volume of "Nihonshoki."

Also, according to ""Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), one of the volumes of "Nihonshoki," and "Shinsen Shojiroku" (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility), Okuninushi was described as the sixth-generation grandson of Susanoo, while he was described as the seventh-generation grandson in a different volume of "Nihonshoki."

Also, according to "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), Arufumi (supplement volumes of explanatory notes in Nihonshoki) of "Nihonshoki" and "Shinsen Shojiroku" (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility), Okuninushi was described as the sixth-generation grandson of Susanoo, while he was described as the seventh-generation grandson in a different volume of "Nihonshoki."
sen.cmt: ダブルクオーテーションのダブりを削除しました。ダブルクオーテーションを修正しました。

sen.j: スサノオの後にスクナビコナと協力して天下を経営し、禁厭（まじない）、医薬などの道を教え、葦原中国の国作りを完成させる。
sen.e: Taking over the work of Susanoo, Okuninushi worked with Sukunabikona to control the country, teach kinen (incantations) and medicine, and complete creation of Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (a word to express the country or a location in Japan).

Taking over the work of Susanoo, Okuninushi worked with Sukunabikona to control the country, teach kinen (incantations) and medicine, and complete the creation of Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (a word to express the country or a location in Japan).

sen.cmt: 時制を一部修正しました。

sen.j: 国土を天孫・ニニギに譲って杵築（きづき）の地に隠退、後に出雲大社の祭神となる。
sen.e: Okuninushi then gave the country to Tenson Ninigi, the grandson of Amateraso-Omikami (the sun goddess), withdrew to the land of Kizuki, and later was enshrined at Izumo Taisha Shrine.
Okuninushi then gave the country to Tenson Ninigi, the grandson of Amateraso-Omikami (the sun goddess), withdrew to the land of Kizuki, and later was enshrined at Izumo Taisha Shrine.
Okuninushi then gave the country to Tenson Ninigi, the grandson of Amaterasu Omikami, withdrew to the land of Kizuki, and later was enshrined at Izumo Taisha Shrine.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 因幡の白兎の話、根の国訪問の話、ヌナカワヒメへの妻問いの話が『古事記』に、国作り、国譲り等の神話が『古事記』・『日本書紀』に記載されている。
sen.e: Some parts of "Kojiki" contain a tale of Inaba no shirousagi (the hare of Inaba), a tale of a visit to Nenokuni (Land of the Roots), and the marital relationship with Nunakawa-Hime, and other parts of "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki" contain myths of kunizukuri (creation of the country) and kuniyuzuri (transfer of the land).

Some parts of "Kojiki" contain a tale of Inaba no shirousagi (the hare of Inaba), a tale of a visit to Nenokuni (Land of the Roots), and the marital relationship with Nunakawa-Hime, and other parts of "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki" contain myths of kunizukuri (creation of the country) and kuniyuzuri (transfer of the land).

sen.cmt: ダブルクオーテーションを修正しました。スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 『出雲国風土記』の意宇郡母里郷(現；島根県安来市)の地名起源説話には「八岐大蛇」を大穴持（大国主）命が退治し、その帰りに国譲りの宣言をしたとある。
sen.e: According to the anecdote of the origin of the name of the place called Mori-go, Ou-gun (currently Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture), in "Izumo no Kuni Fudoki," Onamochi-no-Mikoto (Okuninushi) vanquished "Yamata-no-Orochi (big snake with eight heads' and on the way home declared transfer of the land.

According to the anecdote of the origin of the name of the place called Mori-go, Ou-gun (currently Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture), in "Izumo no Kuni Fudoki," Onamochi-no-Mikoto (Okuninushi) vanquished "Yamata-no-Orochi (big snake with eight heads' and on the way home declared transfer of the land.

According to the anecdote of the origin of the name of the place called Mori-go, Ou-gun (currently Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture), in "Izumo no Kuni Fudoki," Onamochi no Mikoto (Okuninushi) vanquished 'Yamata no Orochi' (big snake with eight heads) and on the way home declared transfer of the land.
sen.cmt: ダブルクオーテーションを修正しました。

tit.cmt: 小タイトル用に小文字にしました。

sen.j: 大国主は色々な女神との間に多くの子供をもうけている。
sen.e: Okuninushi and many different goddesses had many children.
Okuninushi and many different goddesses had many children.
Okuninushi and many different goddesses had many children.

sen.j: 古事記には180柱、日本書紀には181柱と書かれている。
sen.e: Okuninushi had 180 child gods according to Kojiki and 181 according to Nihonshoki.
Okuninushi had 180 child gods according to Kojiki and 181 according to Nihonshoki.
Okuninushi had 180 child gods according to Kojiki and 181 according to Nihonshoki.

sen.j: 正妻であるスサノオの娘のスセリビメについては、記述がない
sen.e: None of the mythologies above mentioned Suseri-Bime, who was a daughter of Okuninushi's legal wife, Susanoo.
None of the mythologies above mentioned Suseri-Bime, who was a daughter of Okuninushi's legal wife, Susanoo.
None of the mythologies above mentioned Suseri-Bime, who was a daughter of Susanoo and Okuninushi's legal wife.
sen.cmt: 一部翻訳を変更しました。

sen.j: 高志の国の奴奈川姫命（沼河比売）についても記紀神話での記述はないが、葦原中国平定において大国主の子として登場する建御名方神（タケミナカタ）が奴奈川姫との間の子であるという伝承が残されている。
sen.e: The mythologies above also did not mention Nunagawahime-no-Mikoto (Nunakawa-Hime) of Koshi-no-Kuni; however, there has been a myth that Takeminakata-no-Kami, who was mentioned as a child of Okuninushi at the time of conquest of Ashihara no Nakatsukuni, was a child born to Okuninushi and Nunagawahime-no-Mikoto.

The mythologies above also did not mention Nunagawahime-no-Mikoto (Nunakawa-Hime) of Koshi-no-Kuni; however, there has been a myth that Takeminakata-no-Kami, who was mentioned as a child of Okuninushi at the time of conquest of Ashihara no Nakatsukuni, was a child born to Okuninushi and Nunagawahime-no-Mikoto.

The mythologies above also did not mention Nunagawahime no Mikoto (Nunakawa-Hime) of Koshi no Kuni (Land of Koshi); however, there has been a myth that Takeminakata no Kami, who was mentioned as a child of Okuninushi at the time of conquest of Ashihara no Nakatsukuni, was a child born to Okuninushi and Nunagawahime no Mikoto.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。高志の国→Land of Koshi としました。

sen.j: 最初の妻のヤガミヒメとの間に木俣神
sen.e: Kinomata-no-Kami was born to Okuninushi and his first wife, Yagami-Hime.
Kinomata-no-Kami was born to Okuninushi and his first wife, Yagami-Hime.
Kinomata no Kami was born to Okuninushi and his first wife, Yagami-Hime.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 宗像三女神のタキリビメとの間にアヂスキタカヒコネ（賀茂大神）・タカヒメ（シタテルヒメ）の二神
sen.e: Ajisukitakahikone (Kamo-no-Okami) and Taka-Hime (Shitateru-Hime) were born to Okuninushi and Takiri-Bime, who was one of the Munakata Sanjojin (three goddesses enshrined at Munakata Taisha shrine).
Ajisukitakahikone (Kamo-no-Okami) and Taka-Hime (Shitateru-Hime) were born to Okuninushi and Takiri-Bime, who was one of the Munakata Sanjojin (three goddesses enshrined at Munakata Taisha shrine).

sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: カムヤタテヒメとの間に事代主
sen.e: Kotoshironushi-no-Kami was born to Okuninushi and Kamuyatate-Hime.
Kotoshironushi-no-Kami was born to Okuninushi and Kamuyatate-Hime.
Kotoshironushi no Kami was born to Okuninushi and Kamuyatate-Hime.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: ヤシマムジの娘のトトリヒメとの間にトリナルミ。
sen.e: Torinarumi was born to Okuninushi and Totori-Hime, who was a daughter of Yashimamuji.
Torinarumi was born to Okuninushi and Totori-Hime, who was a daughter of Yashimamuji.
Torinarumi was born to Okuninushi and Totori-Hime, who was a daughter of Yashimamuji.

sen.j: 以降、トリナルミの系譜がトリナルミ以下9代列挙されている。
sen.e: After Torinarumi, there was a record of 9 generations of the Torinarumi genealogy.
After Torinarumi, there was a record of 9 generations of the Torinarumi genealogy.

sen.cmt: 数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 大国主の求愛を拒んだ女性に、出雲郡宇賀郷のアヤトヒメがある。
sen.e: Ayatohime from Uka-go, Izumo-gun, rejected Okuninushi's love.
Ayatohime from Uka-go, Izumo-gun, rejected Okuninushi's love.
Ayato-Hime from Uka-go, Izumo-gun, rejected Okuninushi's love.
sen.cmt: アポストロフィーを修正しました。

sen.j: 拒んだ理由として、スセリヒメが嫉妬深い性格であること、スセリヒメの嫉妬を想像したヤカミヒメが子供を斐川町直江で放棄し、故郷の因幡の国にもどってしまったことがあげられ、「出雲風土記」に記載されている。
sen.e: She rejected him because Suseri-Bime (his legal wife) was a very jealous goddess and also because Yagami-Hime (the first wife), imagining the intensity of jealousy of Suseri-Bime, abandoned her child in Naoe, Hikawa-cho, and returned to her hometown, Inaba, and these reasons were described in 'Izumo Fudoki.'

She rejected him because Suseri-Bime (his legal wife) was a very jealous goddess and also because Yagami-Hime (the first wife), imagining the intensity of jealousy of Suseri-Bime, abandoned her child in Naoe, Hikawa-cho, and returned to her hometown, Inaba, and these reasons were described in 'Izumo Fudoki.'

She rejected him because Suseri-Bime (his legal wife) was a very jealous goddess and also because Yagami-Hime (the first wife), imagining the intensity of jealousy of Suseri-Bime, abandoned her child in Naoe, Hikawa-cho, and returned to her hometown, Inaba, and these reasons were described in 'Izumo Fudoki.'
sen.cmt: アポストロフィーを修正しました。

tit.cmt: 小タイトル用に小文字にしました。

sen.j: 国造りの神、農業神、商業神、医療神などとして信仰されている。
sen.e: Okuninushi has been worshipped as a god of building of a nation, agriculture, commerce, and medicine.
Okuninushi has been worshipped as a god of building nations, agriculture, commerce, and medicine.
Okuninushi has been worshipped as a god of building nations, agriculture, commerce, and medicine.

sen.j: また、「大国」はダイコクとも読めることから、同じ音である大黒天（大黒様）と習合して民間信仰に浸透している。
sen.e: Also, because the first two Chinese characters of Okuninushi can also be pronounced as 'daikoku,' Okuninushi has been syncretized with Daikokuten (Mahakala or Daikoku-sama) that shares that pronunciation and has been accepted in the beliefs of the common people.

Also, because the first two Chinese characters of Okuninushi can also be pronounced as 'daikoku,' Okuninushi has been syncretized with Daikokuten (Mahakala or Daikoku-sama) that shares that pronunciation and has been accepted in the beliefs of the common people.

Also, because the first two Chinese characters of Okuninushi can also be pronounced as 'daikoku' Okuninushi has been syncretized with Daikokuten (Mahakala or Daikoku-sama) that shares that pronunciation and has been accepted in the beliefs of the common people.
sen.cmt: アポストロフィーを修正しました。

sen.j: 子の事代主がえびすに習合していることから、大黒様とえびすは親子と言われるようになった。
sen.e: Because Kotoshironushi-no-Kami, who was a child of Okuninushi, has been syncretized with Ebisu, Daikoku-sama and Ebisu came to be believed as being a parent and a child.
Because Kotoshironushi-no-Kami, who was a child of Okuninushi, has been syncretized with Ebisu, Daikoku-sama and Ebisu came to be believed as being a parent and a child.
Because Kotoshironushi no Kami, who was a child of Okuninushi, has been syncretized with Ebisu, Daikoku-sama and Ebisu came to be believed as being a parent and a child.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

tit.j: 大国主を祀る主な神社
tit.e: Examples of Shrines where Okuninushi is Enshrined
Examples of Shrines where Okuninushi is Enshrined

sen.j: 大国主を祀る神社の代表は出雲大社（島根県出雲市）で、他に大神神社（奈良県桜井市）、気多大社（石川県羽咋市）、気多本宮（同七尾市）、大國魂神社（東京都府中市 (東京都)）のほか、全国の出雲神社で祀られている。
sen.e: The most famous shrine that enshrines Okuninushi is Izumo Taisha Shrine (Izumo City, Shimane Prefecture), and other examples are Omiwa-jinja Shrine (Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture), Kita Taisha Shrine (Hakui city, Ishikawa Prefecture), Keta-hongu Shrine (Nanao City, Ishikawa Prefecture), Okunitama-jinja Shrine (Fuchu City, Tokyo Prefecture), and Izumo-jinja Shrines across the country.

The most famous shrine that enshrines Okuninushi is Izumo Taisha Shrine (Izumo City, Shimane Prefecture), and other examples are Omiwa-jinja Shrine (Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture), Kita Taisha Shrine (Hakui city, Ishikawa Prefecture), Keta-hongu Shrine (Nanao City, Ishikawa Prefecture), Okunitama-jinja Shrine (Fuchu City, Tokyo Prefecture), and Izumo-jinja Shrines across the country.

The most famous shrine that enshrines Okuninushi is Izumo Taisha Shrine (Izumo City, Shimane Prefecture), and other examples are Omiwa-jinja Shrine (Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture), Kita Taisha Shrine (Hakui City, Ishikawa Prefecture), Keta-hongu Shrine (Nanao City, Ishikawa Prefecture), Okunitama-jinja Shrine (Fuchu City, Tokyo Prefecture), and Izumo-jinja Shrines across the country.
sen.cmt: City 大文字にしました。
